reviewText:
Tons of funny references, a catchy soundtrack that's bound to get stuck in your brain, and a variety of ways to build up your fighter. You start out trying to avenge your father's death by recovering the Medallion he gave to you and your brother. Along the way you gain allies and rivals as you build yourself up to being a true Contender.

Pros: Great 16-bit looking graphics and music. The music was catchy and the fights remind me of an elaborate game of rock-paper-scissors. Managing all the aspects of your career (money, health, stamina, hunger, strength, agility, and stamina) is challenging and you really need to think about what you are going to prioritize. The game has some replay value as you'll probably find your second run through MUCH easier than the first. The game also takes place over several locations, allowing a change of scenery. Looking back after my initial start there are several 'mercy' options available if you get 'stuck'.

Cons: The game can be extremely grindy. Each day your stats automatically go down, so you're constantly having to train to keep them up. The only thing that really 'stays' are your skills/perks. Losing fights can be a major setback, requiring long periods of re-training and recovery. Running out of money and being too hungry/tired to work can be a pitfall for some players. These can be circumvented, but it tends to nudge the player toward min-maxing in order to ensure a smooth progression.

Overall it is a really fun game, and definitely worth $9.99 . I'm really looking forward to future balancing by the devs, to make a great game fantastic.

It's not.

reviewText:
I wasn't expecting to write a negative review for this game, in fact I wanted to enjoy this game for what it was: a simulation tycoon. I usually enjoy those kinds of games, for example; Game Dev Tycoon and Thrillville are two of my favourite games ever. The key to making a fun tycoon game is achieving the feeling of always advancing and making progress, and having the player overcome and figure out challenges, wants and needs without them feeling like its a 'grind' and/or actual work.

For the first hour of this game, I was really getting into it. My character who I named 'Joker' was getting introduced to new and exciting characters, game mechanics and overall making solid progress within the game's story tree. I was really enjoying the experience the game was giving to me, from little references that made me chuckle to having me think on my feet and trying to beat my opponent. Sometimes I'd win, sometimes I'd lose. Either way I'd learn from the results of those fights and try better next time.

However, the more I went on, 'Punch Club' became more of a chore than an actual fun experience. For starters, one of the game mechanics that really bugged me was the fact that the stats you were improving each day would ultimately get decreased substantially at the start of a new day. This wouldn't bug me as much if the amount of effort I was putting in to improve my stats and skills wasn't a large amount. But it was. Certain gym equipment and gear will boost either one or three of your stats; strength, agility and stamina. However you can only use a certain piece of equipment for a short duration of time during the day before your character becomes tired and drained. This can be a problem as during those training sessions, the amount of points/energy you obtain is only in small increments, and the feeling of getting so close to a new stat rank only for it to be bumped down substantially the very next day is one of complete and utter annoyance.

Some people might have a problem with the fact that the fight simulations are just that; simulations. You don't control the character, instead you select a limited amount of skills and abilities at the start of each round in a match. You then press start and watch as your guy clashes with your opponent boxer. Either getting the upper hand or getting completely demolished. For myself, this wasn't a problem for me, as the challenge in of itself was trying to select the right skills that would successfully disarm and put my opponent at a disadvantage in order for me to grab the win. However the problem I have is the ranking system and how it 'changes'. You could be a day before a match, training hard to boost up stats that will ultimately crush the higher ranking opponent. Only to have on the actual day be challenged by an opponent that is completely different, sometimes even stronger in areas you worked so hard to boost. I hate to be one of those people, but it really does unfair when the game itself pulls a 180 on you at the very last minute.

Positive-wise, the game's presentation is absolutely great! The retro music and graphics really provide that nostalgic feel and give a great feeling when you're simulating matches or just exploring the game's world. And for that side of things, I'll give the developer credit where credit is due.

Overall, while having a great start, 'Punch Club' ultimately falls flat on its face due to the weight of its complexity, to me the objective of a game is to give the player some time away from the tiresome situations of life. I don't want to play a game that ends up making me bored, stressed and even downright annoyed because of its seemingly unfair gameplay.

Thank you for reading~

This is my opinion btw, so don't get worked up over it. I respect people who truly enjoy this game and are having fun, as I wish I could experience what makes the game so great for those people.

reviewText:
I liked it, but couldn't recommend it.

The game has a promising beginning; real story motivation to train, tournaments, objects to buy, fights with thugs / muggers and a world with interesting characters that slowly opens up. Act 1 & 2 generally plays by managing your job and training, however act 3 is where the game falls apart; the story becomes messy, the world shuts down and the grind begins.  The ending is abrupt, somewhat confusing and unsatisfactory.

The main feature of training is what discipline one picks; strength, agility or stamina. The system is poorly balanced, with agility being easy mode and the others painful to play. In contrast the fights are pretty good (even so the only input is skill setup between rounds). The best aspect about this game IMO is the atmosphere (aside from the slaughter of pop culture references) which captures that of an amateur fighter in the 80s-90s.

This game made me laugh, sad and happy. I liked it, but wouldn't recommend it due to the suspicion that not all planned content was delivered, and that other people may not be as enthusiastic about casual MMA.

reviewText:
As a review/recommendation I would say to wait on this game. I am not saying it is a bad game. If you like the grind, this is the game for you.

That being said, having it be difficult to the point of frustration at the beginning is annoying but then as you use the AGI build (cause it's the only one that works at the momnet) the game gets stupid easy till the very end. Once you get to a certain point (watch out for bears!) you can just spend hours it seems going in a grind circle getting your stats up. Sure it makes the game easier but it's boring as all heck.

Eventually it just comes down to, do you have a AGI build with Dodge/Counterattack? Good. Spam your AGI training and just make sure your in window'd mode so you can back and forth between your browser and the game.

I did enjoy the retro look just WAY to grindy for me. Beat it, glad I played it but wouldn't recommend it till some of the other skill trees get worked out.

reviewText:
I liked it, but couldn't recommend it.

The game has a promising beginning; real story motivation to train, tournaments, objects to buy, fights with thugs / muggers and a world with interesting characters that slowly opens up. Act 1 & 2 generally plays by managing your job and training, however act 3 is where the game falls apart; the story becomes messy, the world shuts down and the grind begins.  The ending is abrupt, somewhat confusing and unsatisfactory.

The main feature of training is what discipline one picks; strength, agility or stamina. The system is poorly balanced, with agility being easy mode and the others painful to play. In contrast the fights are pretty good (even so the only input is skill setup between rounds). The best aspect about this game IMO is the atmosphere (aside from the slaughter of pop culture references) which captures that of an amateur fighter in the 80s-90s.

This game made me laugh, sad and happy. I liked it, but wouldn't recommend it due to the suspicion that not all planned content was delivered, and that other people may not be as enthusiastic about casual MMA.

reviewText:
This game is not complete.

Countless game breaking bugs:

Sometimes every button, person, and location is unclickable which forces you to save/quit, then restart the game - this can be a huge problem.
Some necessary locations, if not discovered earlier in the game, will be wholly unavailable (China Town, a location where you heal for cash).
You are unable to travel to the end-game location, so if you hit a bug that requires a restart, you will never be able to complete the game.
Despite the patch today, AGI is still significantly stronger than any other build type by far.  This makes facing AGI NPCs in the end game an absolute nightmare, and sometimes you have to rely on luck to win the fights (note: STR build with 45 unlocked skill slots, stats are 13/12/12, and 14 passive skills).  With a 4/13/4 AGI build I can breeze through the entire game without every changing my skill builds in any fight.

I have various other qualms with this game (eg. Holy ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥, does every game now have to slam nostalgic pop culture references down my throat?), but preference aside I'd suggest NOT buying, and/or refunding this game until it is actually complete.

reviewText:
The grind is real.  This game is, at first glance, very cool.  I like the retro feel, and the concept is pretty solid.  However, I have a lot of problems with it.  At the end of every day, you lose a certain amount of points in all of your skills (Strength, Agility, Stamina).  It's a pretty hefty loss, which makes little sense.  I can see there being a loss if you're not training every day, but it should be a little more forgiving.  Just got your strength up to 7 with an hour to spare in the day?  Well, it's back to six now.  Train more...  Oh, and your other stats dropped too.  It makes the game very boring, and I find that I can't explore the other stuff in the game because I'm constantly trying to A.) Train, B.) Work a job so I can eat food to C.) Pay for the gym and train more.  I really do like the idea of the game, but its way too grindy for my tastes.

The fights themselves are...interesting.  If you like being utterly dominated by guys with stats far inferior to yours, then you'll have a good time.  I fought a guy with 2/1/2 stats vs my 5/4/5 and he knocked me out in the first round and defeated me in the second.  You'll have a tough time with any fighter whose stats are close to yours, and if they have a stamina score that's at all higher than yours, you can basically forget it.  A fighter with a 2/3/7 will pretty much dominate my 7/4/6.  Granted, maybe I'm early in the game yet and don't have the additional skills all these second rate fighters seem to have (they all have four skills and a perk to my three skills), but it largely seems futile even fighting these guys.  You train and train and train to see your stats inch up almost imperceptibly only to know that the guy you face is likely going to wipe the floor with you despite having inverior statistics.  Your stamina drains way faster than theirs, and once they knock you down, it's a waiting game for them to finish it.  You might have a lot more HP than them, and the fight might start off good for you, but your stamina will soon be in the single digits and you'll be knocked down.  Over and over.  Until your HP advantage is erased and you lose.  Again. I fought some crocadile in the sewer, had him down to 2 HP, then he basically just kept knocking me down, taking me from over 30 to 0 without me having touched him.  Your fighter will miss all the time, wasting precious stamina, while they nibble at you.  One fight saw them throw 8 unanswered punches at me, connecting with each one.  Sure, I swung at them, but missed.  We had the exact same agility, but your hit probability will almost always be lower.

I think my fighter has a 50% win rate.  Maybe that's the point of the game, but it's frustrating and detracts from a great concept.

All in all, I really enjoy the concept, but unless you like being constantly frustrated and annoyed, I wouldn't recommend it.   Maybe they'll reduce the grind.

reviewText:
I really tried to like this game. I really did. But the flaws just stick out like a sore thumb.

In punch club, you play as a son to a dad who was shot killed by an unknown, he tells you to do better than what he did. So now you have to take on fighting, and find out who killed your father. The story is decent and he does drive you to find out just what happened.

The game starts off a little easy, as any game that doesn't require your input. You unlock new places while looking after yourself, working to earn money, eating, sleeping, keeping yourself happy. All while trying to get stronger/quicker/tougher to make sure that the next fights that you do are in your favour.
However, when you do play this, your stat decrease is way too quick, I understand that you can get upgrades so they don't drop below a certain number. But, each upgrade makes the next one more expensive. And it's way too difficult and unfair to make sure that you can buy food to keep yourself nourished. Otherwise, your f'ed. And I know you can get a couple of meals from the guy in the hoodie. But after a while, he refuses. And there is actually a point where you have technically lost. If you can't feed yourself, your doomed. And you have to start the game all over again.

Overall, a poorly made game, can be improved if stat decrease is lowered, I would not recommend this game.

reviewText:
A promising title which falls short...

Pros:
+ Pixel art
+ 80s and 90s references

Cons:
- Soundtrack is too repetitive
- Story is shallow (its a piece of crap without the references actually)
- Gameplay: Its nothing but a grindfest. You can only beat it by doing the same things over and over again.
- Game mechanics: Even that sim part doesnt make any sense it is acceptable for a game like this to push players to grinding. However, actual fighting mechanics are broken. You can knockout an opponent in 1 round, and with the same stats and skill you can lose to same opponent. Its pure luck if your character wants to attack or just stays and try to defend.
- Once again, its pure GRINDFEST.

Final verdict:
It has some cool ideas there and there but totally broken, short and grinding. 4/10  And that points goes to undeniable charm of its pixelart. Gameplaywise its 1/10.

reviewText:
I'm enjoying this game alot more than I expected. You're a young man who wants to become the best boxer he can be who was orphaned at a young age due to your father getting murdered by a mysterious man. The story is very much like the original rocky where you start of as a loser nobody with alot of talent and you have to move your way up through hard-work and talent. Gameplay-wise you manage your characters schedule and work towards improving your skills while gathering enough money for your expenses and training equipment.

The fighting is automatic but you have alot of perks/skills/technique's to unlock and allocate for each fight, inbetween each round you can tell your boxer which skills and technique's to use and while this may sound boring, it's very enjoyable.

In suhort :The sprite art is excellent and the music is quite nice if maybe a bit repetitive. The game is very grindy but it does so intentionally as improving your character feels very satisfying. It takes some experimenting to figure out which training and jobs work best for your goals, And the game is very passive, but it's a very enjoyable time-filler and I really hope the company makes more games like this.

reviewText:
I'd give this game a 8/10.

There's plenty of skills to use, 4 different skill tree's Basic, Turtle, Tiger, Bear. Each one is based around a different stat point. You can unlock every skill in all 4 Tree's if you want, it's not required to beat the game but it's an option for completionists.

You honestly start out without a clue on what you are doing and you learn as you go just like the Main character.

Some of the enemies are OP, however nobody is unbeatable.

There's a nice variety of side-quests and fights to do such as fighting Pizza Loving Crocodiles/Aligators that live in a sewer.

HOWEVER I do have to mention that there is SOME luck-based elements in this game. You will feel like a god and then RNGesus will step in and your next opponent will drop a Sick combo on you and destroy you making you smash your keyboard and punch a hole in your wall out of anger.


This is a fairly fun game, and will provide atleast 6+ hours of enjoyment.

At the moment there really isn't any replay value unless you want to try to beat the game using a different skill set or to beat your old record, maybe for acheivments.


I highly reccomend buying this game as it's probably the funnest thing I've played in the last 30 days.

First i want to say that this game is enjoyable, from what i can tell with the very little that i've played so far. BUT.. it comes with its merits. Accessing menus can be very buggy. I have a habit of using the ESC key to close down menus in games, if you use it in this one, the menu will be come unresponsive forcing you to close the game and reopen it. This has happened maybe 5 times in the hour that i played. Aside from that, it is very grindy. You have to constantly keep up with your stats to stay competitve with other fighters, while also getting rest, working for pay etc. It is an awesome concept, but in the end it just feels like i am doing a chore.

Pros
- Interesting concept that feels fresh to other sim/management type games.
- Awesome art style/OST
- Variety of skills from what i could see
- Satisfying progression system

Cons
- VERY grindy
- Has some very annoying bugs
- Reptitive
-  Lacking in content

This feels less of a 10$ title and more of a free phone game that should have microtransactions. Pick it up on sale.

reviewText:
Looks beautiful, plays like a semi-interactive novel.

That pretty much sums up my experience with this game.  I expected (or rather hoped) it would allow me to, you know, actually control my boxer and fight my own battles; instead, you select a few choice skills and sit there while your character automatically fights with randomized odds of success.

Understand, you have NO (that means zero) control over your character in combat situations.  It turns into a sequence where your character automatically performs whatever skills you have equipped them with until the fight is over.  The same can be said of all the other 'gameplay' in this shoddy mess, from pizza delivery (which is just a cutscene) to construction (again, just a cutscene) to sleeping, working out -- you name it, not a THING in this game is off rails.

In short, it's a semi-interactive novel.  If you're okay with that, then have fun.  I wanted to actually, you know, do some boxing.  Guess it's back to Punch-Out.

reviewText:
its... interesting, i guess. a sim game that follows a fighter who must compete in many fights to reach the top and solve the mysteries of his father.

Pros:
+fights are satisfying
the way the fighting system works is basically an rng cage match where you select certain moves to give to your character each round. in the fight, each move is selected at random, and there are also passive benefits you can use in battle. after every fight, you get a certain amount of 'skill points' which can be used to select certain benefits to help you in battle. more on those later.

+effective stat system
in order to effectively win fights, you have to train up in three different stats: endurange, agility, and strength. you can do pushups in your garage to train all three at one, go to the gym and train with different methods, or go to your job and make money (as well as a small amount of stats). each stat has a skill tree you can spend your skill points on to level up specific aspects of your most dominant stat. for example, levelling up the agility tree gives you access to new and better dodges, counterattacks, kicks, and a 'copycat' move that mimics the actions of your enemies. this system creates the different builds" that you can follow
date:
and it incentivizes specializing in one skill. i like this a lot.

+branching story & different endings
there are multiple alignments you can follow in the game
recommended: but obviously i can't go very in-depth on them. it's pretty subtle and you have to actively follow the story and stay pretty engaged to get the ending you want. it adds a level of replayability to the game alonside the different skill builds. it's nothing as deep as undertale
hoursPlayed:
but its pretty cool nonetheless.

Cons:
-grindy as all hell
if you don't like grinding and watching a number increase slowly
voteText: then this game is not for you. the only way to increase stats legitimately is to watch your character do pull-ups and hit a tire with a hammer for a long time. it's pretty similar to runescape in the sense that you can feel the difference when your stats are higher

reviewText:
I will would love to be able to give a positive review, however there are some very serious balancing issues that the developers seem to be ignoring.

The acutal game itself is a very interesting boxing manager type game. You decide when your character works, tains, sleeps eats, fights and so on. Trying to balance when to work for food and training to avoid stat decay while fighting in fighting tournaments. Its very interesting with a lovely art style and intriguing story.

There is but one problem. The game includes 3 main stats which are linked to 3 fighting styles. Strength to Bear, Agility to Tiger and Stamina to Turtle. These stats and styles are heavily unbalanced. Agility is easily the strongest. The stat affect your chance to hit and dodge as well as having many skills that reduce damage, making your dodge rely more on agility which seems to be an unintended buff while also lowering the stamina cost. As well as having attacks that cost very little stamina and that rely less on strength to do damage.

Bear and strength are the middle tier. Increasing Strength ups your damage while also increasing the stamina cost for all your attacks and indirectly lower your chance to hit. The style does a lot of damage but without putting lots of points into agility you have zero chance to win fights against agility opponents due to a very low hit chance.

Turtle and stamina is the bottom of the barrel. Turtle style is a stye meant to be based around, you guessed it stamina and toughness. It increases your health and I believe damage resistance. However in a stamina build you will frequently run out of... stamina. Its attacks have the highest stamina cost and porbably the worst damage. Agility opponents also have many, many skills that take apart stamina builds. Skills that lower opponents chance to dodge or making blocked attacks do more damage or lowering block chances.

As it is now simply putting all your points into agility and none into strength and some into stamina will allow you to breeze through the game while the other styles requires a much greater struggle. This would be fine if the developers saw it as a problem which they seem not too. Instead they see it as an invisible difficulty option. This is a horrible way to avoid responsibility for making an unbalanced game and makes me think they are unlikely to change anything. Great concept, well executed, horribly balanced.

reviewText:
** This game gets incredibly grindy towards the last half of the game and kind of loses the management sim aspect of the first half, so dont buy if you dont want to grind out numbers**



If i hadnt already fell in love with the over the top ridiculously 80's feel (In the options you can make the game have retro pixelated graphics for the real 80's arcade vibe) along with all of the little refrences to good movies, comics, TV shows and games i would have an entirely different opinion on how good or bad this game is.  The first half of the game is where it really shines as a management sim / rpg / glorified rock'em sock'em robots spectator sport.  Unfortunately the last half of the game loses its perspective and just turns into watching numbers go up and down until you get the ones you need to beat the other guys higher numbers taking all of the skill out of it.  If the Devs would lower the amount of points you lose per day and make the game less grindy it would double the fun factor but they wouldnt want people to finish their game in like 2 or 3 hours so they'll never do that.

I will note though that the game is a lesson that to become physically fit and stay in shape you constantly need to train in different areas and make sure not to get complacent just grinding out the same thing.  If you ever go to a gym you'll hear they have things like Arm day" or "Leg day" you alternate just enough to build on the muscles a day or so prior. If you abscent mindedly look around waiting while your guy trains he will start gaining less and less from doing that activity and use more food/energy doing it. What you need to do is cycle through the whole gym doing a little bit of each to keep the gains high and burning through food and energy low.  This may confuse some people that play the game thinking that its just showing you how much time you have left on that workout
date: but the developer has confirmed that you are in fact LOSING a percentage of each gained bubble.\n\nI didnt expect this game to try and subtlety try and teach you how to work out effectively. I also didnt expect how damn difficult it is to buy and keep food in the fridge when your also trying to stay the most physically fit for your upcoming fights. You also may have to swap out your abilities mid fight because while your stamina is high the other guy may be doing way waaaay more damage and dumping all your defensive ♥♥♥♥ in order to push for the win is the best course of action
recommended: Each skill tree has something that counteracts the other two so making sure your not taking block when the guy your going up against has something that goes through 40% of your blocked damage. Taking the time between rounds to switch out these things and seeing what works will net you a solid victory and not get your ♥♥♥ whooped.\n\nThis game says to me that to stay still or to put your nose to the grinder is the worst thing to do so to avoid that you need to step back
hoursPlayed: assess your options
voteText:
try to keep an open mind and dont get tunnel vision....like a real fighter. A true fighter is not a mindless emotionless thug but a well oiled machine that is more a lifestyle and less a interest or hobby you watch on UFC because everyones on the bandwagon.



Overall its a fun game for $10 but if you are the type of person who was looking for a deep game that needs constant attention being a fighters coach you would be barking up the wrong tree.  Its more of a Ipad type game that you'd play on the toilet.  As i said at the start if spending days and days grinding out numbers would bore you to tears id steer clear of this game too.  Its a charming casual rock'em sock'em robots game that just needs a hip 80's kid with spikey hair to play it in a commercial.

Can you maintain a life

reviewText:
In short : Addictive and rewarding experience. It’s exactly what it looks like – a retro style from zero to hero story with grind based gameplay with a dose of management. Although monotonous at times, it’s tongue in cheek, stereotypical setting and gratifying level ups will keep you playing to the end which unfortunately is abrupt and disappointing.

In depth review :

Punch Club revolves around a young boxer wannabe who rises to the top in order to avenge his father, whatever sense it makes.
You start as lonely guy living in a small house with his cat and a fishtank. Oh, and you’re broke as hell. After series of mildly interesting events you’re given a chance as a boxer.

This introduces you to what is core element of Punch Club – training, stats and skills. If you’re familiar with Kairosoft’s mobile “Story” series you’ll probably get the picture.
There are three main branches of stats – strength, agility and stamina. The same goes for skills which are divided into a basic set of skills and three advanced, heavily stat-dependent styles.
In consequence you can choose to be a lightning fast fighter, sluggish but powerful heavy hitter or a damage soaking tank sponge. But hold on, it gets a little bit more complex.
One stat has an impact on another. Example – having high strength and punching hard depletes stamina drastically and low agility will make you more likely to miss. Character progression involves tactic, adequate stat training and carefully selected skills.

You’ll be spending lots of time on training which can raise your stats or give exp points for new abilities. But there is a twist. At the end of every day you lose portion of your stats so not only you have to improve them but also maintain them. This is tricky as you also have to find time to earn some money, rest and make stops at convenience store to refill your fridge. Punch Club will force you to manage your time, money and boxer’s path. It can be both frustrating and fun.

Let’s go to the meat of Punch Club, fighting that is. As I said before it relies heavily on stats and abilities. That’s because you have no influence on your bouts aside from setting up your skills and training. Fortunately, I must say that I enjoyed watching and cheering my boxer or moaning in disappointment as you normally would watching match on TV. Punch Club’s advantage is also a variety of fighting scenarios. You’ll be boxing in amateur leagues, professional championships but also in a street fights, illegal matches and special events.

It’s worth mentioning that Punch Club has a little more to it than a career – mostly special events. You may fall in love, chill with your new friend, do some dirty work for a mob boss or traditional fetch quests. Sadly, there’s not much to it. They’re trivial, rather short and in small amounts. There’s also a crossroad in the plot where you chose your path but still, final destination Is the same.

What seems obvious here is a huge, in-the-face influence of 80’s/90’s culture. It’s apparent in the plot, in side quests, in locations, in dialogue, basically everything has this cheesy, yet very likeable vibe to it. You’ll recognize a lot of references with a mild sense of humor – Rocky, Street Fighter, Mortal Kombat, TMNT (yup!) – you name it. With graphics resembling NES/SNES or even arcades it really adds to this feeling which is cozy and familiar.

That’s good and all but there are also some major flaws in Punch Club. It’s short soundtrack will get on your nerve pretty soon as it repeats over and over again. Though gameplay is addicting it’s also pretty repetitive and if you won’t believe the illusion of variety, you’ll get bored easily. What made me especially mad is weak story progression. Was it intended to emulate early action movies or not, it failed to be engaging or compelling. What’s worse, it ends abruptly and ridiculously making me not only disappointed but mad. It’s fun when the ride lasts but the destination makes you wish you never arrived.

Completion time : 13 hours

The good :

-	Addictive and fun gameplay
-	Good 80’s/90’s feeling

The bad :

-	Disasterous ending
-	Monotonous music
-	Rather short

Final score : 7/10

reviewText:
So i bought this game cause it actually looked fun.

Well let me tell you it was one of the best games i have played in such a long time.

The balancing of how your character develops, and the different strategies you can explore are mind numbing.

I finally found a perfect balance, and i beat the game.  It took me 3 restarts and tons of frustration but i finally did it.

Time management if key.


All in all this game took me back to when games were actually fun to play, I will be following this team closely to see if there are new games they will be developing in the future.  +1 to the Devs, +1 for bringing back all my favorite 1980's action/cartoons to life again.

You guys are amazing.

Seriously, you will spend 2-3 hours in the game and get nothing accomplished. reviewText:
I will would love to be able to give a positive review, however there are some very serious balancing issues that the developers seem to be ignoring.

The acutal game itself is a very interesting boxing manager type game. You decide when your character works, tains, sleeps eats, fights and so on. Trying to balance when to work for food and training to avoid stat decay while fighting in fighting tournaments. Its very interesting with a lovely art style and intriguing story.

There is but one problem. The game includes 3 main stats which are linked to 3 fighting styles. Strength to Bear, Agility to Tiger and Stamina to Turtle. These stats and styles are heavily unbalanced. Agility is easily the strongest. The stat affect your chance to hit and dodge as well as having many skills that reduce damage, making your dodge rely more on agility which seems to be an unintended buff while also lowering the stamina cost. As well as having attacks that cost very little stamina and that rely less on strength to do damage.

Bear and strength are the middle tier. Increasing Strength ups your damage while also increasing the stamina cost for all your attacks and indirectly lower your chance to hit. The style does a lot of damage but without putting lots of points into agility you have zero chance to win fights against agility opponents due to a very low hit chance.

Turtle and stamina is the bottom of the barrel. Turtle style is a stye meant to be based around, you guessed it stamina and toughness. It increases your health and I believe damage resistance. However in a stamina build you will frequently run out of... stamina. Its attacks have the highest stamina cost and porbably the worst damage. Agility opponents also have many, many skills that take apart stamina builds. Skills that lower opponents chance to dodge or making blocked attacks do more damage or lowering block chances.

As it is now simply putting all your points into agility and none into strength and some into stamina will allow you to breeze through the game while the other styles requires a much greater struggle. This would be fine if the developers saw it as a problem which they seem not too. Instead they see it as an invisible difficulty option. This is a horrible way to avoid responsibility for making an unbalanced game and makes me think they are unlikely to change anything. Great concept, well executed, horribly balanced.

reviewText: So I started off really loving this game, I went with a Strength based build but as the game went on, it became increasingly clear that the game is so poorly balanced that if you choose any build besides Agility, you might as well ♥♥♥♥ing kill yourself.  The game WAS a lot of fun but as I neared the game it became increasingly frustrating that I couldn't play and win the way I wanted to and in a way that was clearly intended for players.  Overall, the game had a lot of cute pop culture references but at the end of the day it's a grindy ♥♥♥♥ing mess that I am walking away from.

reviewText:
At this time i would say i would not recommend this game to anyone i know.

The game play is decent
but lacks content to keep anyone interested due too the short game play
Graphics are good.
The learning curve is some what steep due to the player having figure out stat points
and move set combos. (Stats seem too be pretty unbalanced or and broken)

You have only three choices of fighting stances

The way of the bear (Mainly str build requires players to understand what moves to choose from either high damage and high energy drain one of the hard builds too use *Its as if you are setting the game difficultly level*)

The way of the tiger Agility Build" Its all about dodging attacks and countering one of the most OP builds but was supposedly nerfed in current update* It was said too be the most easy way of going through the game and some are still saying it is.

The way of the turtle  "Stamina build" This one has been on the complaint list of players supposedly it is the hardest build on the game drains energy way to fast sure it does.. like way of the bear doesn't?

again these builds you just need too figure out what moves to use.

Other than all that...

I have found this game to be the most buggy and glitchy and annoying game on my list due too the npcs you go against having over powering traits and skill sets.

Dodge
recommended:
countering seems like their moves execute 90 -100% of the time and you struggle through things
sure a challenge is great but this game.... it is just... not there



The price tag is about 10usd if you ask me thats a bit much
for a game that does not have much usually to be expected.. but if you've played this game you'll know what kind of headaches you can run into.

The side quest presents more of a challenge than the main story line does....

Graphics 3/5
Content 1/5
Main story line content 1/5 (Side quest rating as well)
Over all game play and rating  i give it a 2 out of 5"

reviewText:
I wanted to like Punch Club but it just has too many problems.

Problems:
* Lose stats every day so you lose all the progress you've made training.
* Practically no interactavity in fights. Fights are just stats VS stats instead of something fun
* Strength builds more difficult to pull off than other builds because high strength is dependant on high stamina so you need to level up both strength and stamina to pull off a good strength build. So you have to grind way more stats than you would for an agility build for example.
* Awful ending that is ripped straight out of Empire Strikes Back.
* You never get to actually fight the guy that you grind through the entire game to fight. It pulls off some ridiculous game twist in the story that isn't satisfying at all and left me bitter that all the time i spent training to fight the final guy was worthless because you never get to even fight him.
* It's ridiculously grindy. It was getting to the point that in order not to lose stats i was grinding fitness stats and just consuming a ton of energy drinks and food just because i didn't want to spend time sleeping and end up losing stats.

I would not recommend this game and as much as i wanted to like this game i ended up finding it a major disapointment.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought this game due to the great looking sprites and retro styling, along with a fair bit of humor from what I saw before it was released. I haven't put much time into it yet because like many others, I found this game to be more mobile 'game' than game. You train, you lose stats, you retrain over and over. The game isn't really such a thing, unless you just want to play excel sheet trainer. You never actually do anything to affect the outcomes of fights other than slotting abilities and watching your fighter stand in a ring.

In all honesty, this feels like a mobile game meant for microstransactions to buy things to keep your stats from falling, except even those games have spots where you can tap around on the screen to do literally anything besides travel from spot to spot.

I really do want to like this game. Good sprites, good asthetic, and a good name. The reality though? There's no game to this thing. It's just a RNG machine that you pull the crank on every now and then.

reviewText: Played this game nonstop the first day I bought it, it slowly teetered off but was still addicting when I had time to play, but as soon as I got to day 232 with 18 HOURS into this game, the game  glitches and I cannot move on the map or in my current home. I cant even Alt-F4 out, so I am force to open Task Manager and manually close it. When I open the game back up my file is completely gone. Incredibly Game breaking bug, if this had happened in the 1st hour or two of playing I would be fine, but what a complete waste of time and money. Don't buy this game, save your money and time. Incredibly dissapointed, and legitimately want my money back.

reviewText:
First: I don't want to you to not buy this game, just inform you what you're getting into.

The game seems fun and it definitely is, but not for long. The early- to mid-game is full of different opportunities, which are fun to do, and the character progression is very cool.
But when you reach late-game, it becomes very stale, repetitive and tedious. You spend 0,5-2hrs doing the same stuff over and over, to prepare for the fights.
And even if you are prepared well, you have to fight the RNG, too.
Especially the late-game-chore and RNG is something, that works against the replayability and made me stop going for all achievements.

The playtime of a blind playthrough is between 6-8hrs, so pick it up if you find the price reasonable for a single playthrough of that length, because you may not get more out of it.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
After putiting 11+ hrs into it, originally being a must buy and novel, and nostalgic feel to this interesting game, the grind heavy focus, plus the late game falling off of the rest of the earlier parts of the game make the later half very dull, and not as amusing as the earlier plot/story, fights, and build up of excitement that the game initially brings.  Many of the times you have this trial and error phase of first playthroughs or the long first one if you're trying to unlock/complete/master the game in one go, are exhausting.  The walking about, text speed, cutscenes, and lack of information on numbers is just frustratingly long/slow/unnecessary.  Great great potential for the story and gameplay if it were tweaked a bit.  Many bugs and glitches are just upsetting, however few there are.  Looking forward to lengthening the game, and juicening up the story/mechanics/endgame or whatever parts to it.

It's suffering from being a short and sweet game, and a grind, late game, wanting to fight em all kinda game.

Do I want pokemon with memes?  Or do I want a riveting story where the gameplay is efficient and works well to bring about the immersion from earlier all throughout to an astounding finale?

It falls short between being both and it's just weird.

Try it out on sale or if you really really enjoy an automatic/semi turn based fighter with some cool concepts and artwork.  However, this game needs to be worked upon much more to be great.

reviewText: I beat the game in about 10 hours, and looking back, it really wasn't that fun or interesting at all after the first hour. The game tries to hide the fact that you do the same thing every day by having different locations to train and fight, but as you progress, it basically gives up on even doing that and then makes you stay in one location to do the same thing over and over.

reviewText:
I wanted to like Punch Club but it just has too many problems.

Problems:
* Lose stats every day so you lose all the progress you've made training.
* Practically no interactavity in fights. Fights are just stats VS stats instead of something fun
* Strength builds more difficult to pull off than other builds because high strength is dependant on high stamina so you need to level up both strength and stamina to pull off a good strength build. So you have to grind way more stats than you would for an agility build for example.
* Awful ending that is ripped straight out of Empire Strikes Back.
* You never get to actually fight the guy that you grind through the entire game to fight. It pulls off some ridiculous game twist in the story that isn't satisfying at all and left me bitter that all the time i spent training to fight the final guy was worthless because you never get to even fight him.
* It's ridiculously grindy. It was getting to the point that in order not to lose stats i was grinding fitness stats and just consuming a ton of energy drinks and food just because i didn't want to spend time sleeping and end up losing stats.

I would not recommend this game and as much as i wanted to like this game i ended up finding it a major disapointment.

reviewText: The writing is just a bunch of pop culture references. Not funny ones. More like the game is begging you to think it's cool. And it's not. It's boring. Your stats drain at an insane pace, in this world the minute you stop working out your muscles begin to atrophy. You have to work a job to pay for food and stuff, which makes the stat drains even worse. And when your stats get where you want them, you can choose to fight someone, and just watch the fight happen. By the fourth or fifth fight, this will no longer be interesting. Honestly, everytime I tried to play this game, I fell asleep. Save your money, this one's not worth it.

reviewText:
Take your fighter from his first fight to being world champion and solving the mystery that surrounds your fathers death, in this excellent boxing management game.

You control every aspect of your boxers life, what you eat, how you train, how much you see your girlfriend... I could go on. You can't directly control your actions in fights but do choose the roster of punches, kicks, block, and dodges you will use in each round of fighting. You gain moves and abilities to use in these fights at a steady pace that manages to be frequent enough for your tactics to be constantly evolving but spread out enough to not let you be bogged down in moves that come obsolete in the next hour of gameplay.  However your levelling is separate from your base stats, which will constantly drop to males spending your time training extra important. This provides the main challenge of the gam as balancing your skills against your needs is difficult however can make the game feel grindy at times, even to people who enjoy working out the most efficient routine.

The game is full of 80s nostalgia and pop culture references. Even the main story line feels like it's been ripped out of an 80s movie and pays homage to plenty of your favourite movies from the decade. And the graphical style compliment this beautifully.

Overall a very balanced game, with a fun if not batdropping insane story and great visuals. Just can be a grind fest at times. But it's a grind fest worth fighting through. Now, if you don't mind I have to get back to to the speed bag before my energy drops anymore than it already has.

reviewText: The game sounded really fun and good. But when I actually got to play it I couldn't bare it for more than an hour and got my refund.\nMy problems with the game were mainly the grinding that got boring and was the majorty of  what you do in the game play , and the literally forced" plot. Why is forced plot a problem? In theory it's quite good. But when you calculate the exact amount of money and time you want to spend in a place before you go to your house to sleep/eat and insted get transported around the city with *no way* of skipping the dialog or speeding up the text(which just got really annoying the more I played).\nA way to solve it is to let the player choose when to enter the sequance. For example
date:
when you get that wierd suitcase to your house instead of forcing you to start it's event just let me do it whenever I please.
Another problem for me was the fact that you can't tell the difficulity of a fight pre-entring it. There is no indication of what level the fight/quest you're going into requires and once you start a quest you can't quit/stop it.
For me it got really annoying when the pizza guy gave me a job (special delivery) and when I got to it the fight was unwinable for my level.
And in a game where time investment matters
recommended: and thinking ahead about what to do really matters (you can get injured and thus slow your progress for example)  this kind of problems shine and are really

reviewText:
This game is a giant grind. Basically all you do is watch your character train, then watch him fight, then buy skills. The skill tree is somewhat interesting, however you can get all the skills if you grind long enough, meaning your choices only affect how long it takes you to beat the game.

Properly managing your time is important throughout the game but becomes less and less interesting as the game progresses. Early on you have little money and have to manage working, training, sleeping and fighting. Later on all you do is train and fight. You are forced to spend time training as your characters stats decrease at the end of each day. This is especially annoying in the end game because you have to spend large amounts of time watching your character train between every fight.

If you want to play a fighter management game I suggest any of the Monster Rancher games, They offer a lot of the same sort of systems only done much better.

reviewText:
This game is FANTASTIC! I saw a streamer playing it on Twitch for 10 mins and I was hooked.
I LOVE LOVE LOVE this game. So many 80/90s references it's nostalgic! Time management can be a pain, but it is addicting. Seriously one of the best games I have played. And the price is MORE than worth it!!

Pros: 1) Addicting, can play it for many hours!
You can do a play through of each build so much time to plaaaay.
2) The references are amazing. Makes you want to rewatch The rocky series and TMNT.
3) Retro as hell!
4) Game is simple enough to understand, but alos gives you a challenge!
5) You can say Hey yo Adrian" Like Rocky did.. all the time and it not feel stupid.

Cons:  1) There aren't any. So buy this game. Promise you'll enjoy it."

reviewText:
I got way more than my money's worth with this game. If you fancy some micro management and a classic tale of mystery, revenge, and pop-culture easter eggs, you've come to the right place.

10/10 Roy Jackson

reviewText:
Shallow, RNG-based mechanics that are poorly explained. This would be fine if the game didn't take so long. The lack of a speed-up toggle (to accelerate the 5+hours of total training I did in my 10 hour playthrough) makes this a time sink with an unsatisfying conclusion.
No replayability for me because I don't want to spend another 6 hours to get a fully developed character. Even speedrunners would have a difficult time picking this game because 100 days is still about 5 hours due to the training involved (I could see total training time getting around 3 hours if truly min/maxed, but I doubt much lower).
A cutscene theatre would have been nice since they auto-advance frames and you might miss the text.
Fun music, fun graphics. Better to just watch streamer highlights than to play yourself. Pick up if you find yourself with lot of free time to kill and can play this on mobile, or if it goes on sale for <$5.

reviewText:
Train, eat, sleep, work and then repeat.

The game is repetitive and it's easy to get bored after just a few hours.  I think my biggest gripe with the game is that you take no direct part in the fighting.  You train your fighter and then just sit there and switch some moves in and out of the figher's arsenal between rounds.

However, I did like the graphics and the 90's music.  There are also some references to 90's movies and shows you can catch after playing for a bit.  I suggest you look elsewhere to spend your $10.

reviewText:
This game is a giant grind. Basically all you do is watch your character train, then watch him fight, then buy skills. The skill tree is somewhat interesting, however you can get all the skills if you grind long enough, meaning your choices only affect how long it takes you to beat the game.

Properly managing your time is important throughout the game but becomes less and less interesting as the game progresses. Early on you have little money and have to manage working, training, sleeping and fighting. Later on all you do is train and fight. You are forced to spend time training as your characters stats decrease at the end of each day. This is especially annoying in the end game because you have to spend large amounts of time watching your character train between every fight.

If you want to play a fighter management game I suggest any of the Monster Rancher games, They offer a lot of the same sort of systems only done much better.

It is more a grinding game then a strategy one.

reviewText:
Positively one of the best little games ive played recently. This is currently my GoTo game for some mindless fun while chilling out or watching movies. Easy to learn and play, needs a little time to master, Good clean Casual fun, Game is chock full of pop culture references! Jay and silent Bob, Pulp Fiction, Lock stock & Two smoking barrels. Fight Club, The Fighter, Rocky you name it.

PROS
-Easily Casual
-The Pop Culture!
-Charm
-Addictive
-Suprising Depth
-Great Time Waster
CONS
-Needs Character Customization
-Deeper Side Careers (not necessary but could flesh it out)
-More Balance between fighting styles couldnt hurt (agility dominates)

reviewText:
A surprisingly nice sim fighting game that makes you smile.

You play as a Rocky Balboa-like character that has to fight his way to discover who killed your father.
You have to manage things like your fighting stats (Strength, Agility, Stamina), money, health, energy and hunger in order to achieve your goals.
Along the way you meet obvious parodies of characters found in Rocky and other fighting movies.

The game doesn't last long, but it is strongly recommended on discount.

reviewText:
A surprisingly nice sim fighting game that makes you smile.

You play as a Rocky Balboa-like character that has to fight his way to discover who killed your father.
You have to manage things like your fighting stats (Strength, Agility, Stamina), money, health, energy and hunger in order to achieve your goals.
Along the way you meet obvious parodies of characters found in Rocky and other fighting movies.

The game doesn't last long, but it is strongly recommended on discount.

reviewText:
This game can be really unfun. Losing stat points at the end of the day makes sense if you aren't training it, but if you spend the whole ♥♥♥♥ing day training it, it makes literally no sense to lose 90% of what you've done that day.

Eg

Rank 13 Agility
>Spend all day training Agility for a total of 190
>Day ends lose 160

Train all day, every day, no stop and you'll still barely gain anything. Just like real life.


Wait no it gets even worse.

Rank 18 Agility after continously grinding:
Go into amateur play-offs final round.

Guy throws an 14 punch combo, hits all of them for 225 of 230hp, and knocks me down, get up to be punched.

Day ends back down to Rank 17 Agility.


Skillpoints should also be tiered rather than continously just going up, makes it ♥♥♥♥ing ridiculous training to do anything. Can't wait to pay 30 points for block.

reviewText:
This game is awful and no one should play it or support it, and I regret spending more than 2 hours so I can't refund it.

This game has so many problems it's hard to point at any one specific thing that makes it awful, but the combat system that sides towards one specific stat over all the others as being viable (hot tip its agility) is one of the more glaring ones.
Another factor comes from the fact that the dialogue is written incredibly poorly, before mentioning what could be the worst story ever.

Maybe you aren't here for a great game and you're just here to play a cheesy game and realise that 10 dollars doesn't mean quality. But why can't 10 dollars mean fun?

So, assuming you made the right decision and chose agility over all else you are more than likely dealing with the repetitive ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and continuously depriciating stats, meant to emulate actual body building in an almost delightful ironic twist.

But I have fantastic news!

This game is written in c# and is running on a very basic engine.

After spending 7 hours playing through this awful pendatic game I realised that it was written in c#


so I just memory edited the game to max stats, which only slightly improved the game in that I no longer had to deal with their deteriorating stat system

In the year of your lord and saviour Jesus Christ, 2016AD,  people still haven't figured out that proper challenge isn't about forcing the player to go through constant troublesome ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to advance at EVERY stage of gameplay?

God bless you if you had the time and patience to deal with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t mechanics that railroads you into a recursive stat building system where you head from level 8 to 6 so quickly it'll make your head spin, or better yet get an injury after losing a fight making all progress you had made over the last 2 hours null and void until you can afford to go to a doctor.

Personally I just took the easy way out and fixed the game by getting rid of the stat loss every day, because really who even thinks this is a good idea in any way?

Overall, when you look past the lackluster combat system, glaring plotholes, (SPOILERS: your future dad killed your past dad and you had a brother that was never introduced until the very end of the game, wherein you summarily kill him because he wanted to get the magic amulet that CONTROLS TIME. This is all explained within 2 minutes and then pushed off to the side as if never having been brought up in the first place. Oh and then credits roll after the reveal because the game ends before a final fight with dad! I smell DLC to wrap up the story for the BASE GAME, yummy!), and repetitive soundtrack you get a soggy lump of ♥♥♥♥ that was clearly made in less time than it takes to lay out a fat slimy load with more depth than Punch Club. 3/10 steam please refund

reviewText:
I REALLY wanted to like this game, since it has a pretty unique visual style in a sea of 16-bit monstrosities and it appeals to  two interests of mine -- stats and punching things.

And then everything goes downhill from there.

The game is very short, and while there are a few different paths to reach the end, the ending is so abrupt it'll give you whiplash and it reeks of being nothing but unfinished. I also made the mistake of assuming this would have been a completed game, so the new content that came out for it was pretty much unplayable because you lose the ability to access it at the halfway point of the main story.

As for the game mechanics: the daily stat decay is so extreme you have to formulate a very strict training routine and ABSOLUTELY NOT DIVERT from it in order to keep your stats from going through the floor while making very minimal gains. While progressing through the game, you can minimize the reduction of your main stat, but all three are very important. That said, a look at the forums for this game seem to show that the developer is currently in a state of chasing their own tail trying to balance it out, and it's really a mess to behold. I did a little research and it looks like the stat decay works the way it does because if stats get too high, it's fully possible to have a character that's completely  unplayable due to the way stamina/energy is spent during attacks.

In the end, I guess I'm really just disappointed. After pretty much boycotting indie titles for a long time on Steam, I got my hand bit again and I'll remember to be more mindful in the future when choosing games to buy.

reviewText:
Yes, I reccomend this game to both strategy players and fighting game enthusiasts. (Unless you like fighting yourself, because you have no control over your characters attack patterns or combos. As far as I know at least.) In this game you play as a kid whos dad was shot by an unknown man, and without spoiling the plot to much, involves a mysterious medallion which your father told you to hold on to for whatever reason.

Fighting (Probably the most important part of the game):
You can select the kidns of attacks you want to use and methods of protecting yourself, one turn you select dodge, and karate kick. The other maybe soemthing else. However, you do NOT control your character beyond this during a fight. It is completely up to lady luck, and the fighting is somewhat linear in that regard. After you select your actions your character will duke it out with your opponent. There's a stamina system as well. Your actions cost certain amount of stamina, once you run out, if your enemy manages to hit you, you will be knocked to the ground doing extra damage. The higher yor characters strength the more stamina you spend for each attack. You gain some samina back after laying on the ground. There are no forms of KOs in this game, the only way to win is to beat the enemy outright, or have the most health when the match runs out of time. After each round you regain stamina, (Rounds are counted down through seconds during a fight) you will also get to select a new attack. Meanign you can vary up your strategys, but often you do not want to do this.

Different physichal skills.
There are three attributes, strength, agility, and stamina. in that order. There are also four branches. basic skills, (Very balanced, leaning no way when it comes to skills.) way of the bear (Strength) way of the tiger (Agility) and way of the turtle (Stamina). These are all based on the attributes mentioned beforehand. Now you might be wondering, how do I obtain attributes? Well you have to work out. The main thing you'll be doing at the start is training at the gym. You gain skills by selecting a peice of equipment and training on it, this consumes a variety of status points as I call them from your character. I'll explain that later. You can not work out forever as well, you do run out of time and the day ends, once the day ends you lose your stats. So, it is very important you continue to work out. You can also do steroids, you cheating fiend.

Managing your charachters life:
Welp, now its turned into sims. Just kidding your still playing punch club. Despite the way that first sentence might of sounded, I actually enjoy this. You have to go to a crocery store, and buy food, which is tored in your fridge automatically. This is where status poitns come into play. You have health which is lost during fights, food, which is lost through of variety of actions including sleeping and working out. Happieness, which can be gained through fights and watching TV. All of these are nescascary. You cannot work out without food or energy, and when you are sad, your workout efficiency is severely decreased. Health effects the amount of hit points you start each fight with. Low health equals lower HP. This all sounds very simple but it can get somewhat complicated, as you ahve to balance the needs of you character. There is also a tiem limit to each day, well, I owuldn't really call it a time limit per say, its more like paying taxes. You have to give up attributes at the end of each day, you lose time on the clock with every action you take, even going from place ot place. Lastly, money, which is important as well. You spend money on going to the gym, on food, steroids, and many other things. It is probably one of the most important parts of the game. So, in conclusion, I like this game a lot, it's also cheap! So buy it. Naow. Buy it naow. NAOWWWWWWWWWW!

reviewText:
*Edit*

After 14h there is a major flaw in the game, one of the three build types is vastly superior to the other two. Namely agility. I wanted to play a strength fighter and when you run into a character with high agi and some type of damage reflect it becomes nearly impossible to deal with. Actually any agi fighter really, during one sequence where you have to fight 4 different fighters I dominated the first, then had to overtrain a crazy amount to barely defeat the second (agi based). The next two fighters, one of whom was supposed to be a big deal I utterly demolished without any more training.

I still recommend this game but there are some serious issues and I'm unsure if they will be rectified.

**Original (6h in)**

I was going to wait for a steam sale to pick this up but I watched the twitch feed for a bit and decided I'd rather have it now. I'm glad I did.

Onto the game itself, there are the occassional frustrations of the RNGod which have my fighter losing to someone who I was able to beat multiple times before and have improved my fighter since then. I'm not a fan of how quickly stats are lost, I understand they did that so you can't just train up and wreck but it makes it hard to gain stats and very hard to gain stats in multiple categories which admittedly the game advises against. Then of course the early seemingly 100% chance of getting robbed when you have a significant amount of cash on you making early upgrades to the garage essentially not possible.

Despite my minor frustrations with the gameplay this is a fantastic game and I'd recommend it to people who like rpg/sim/management types.

reviewText:
This game is what happens when an RPG meets a boxing manager.

You play a character following a storyline, leveling stats and skills, doing sidequests looking for a conclusion to your quest for revenge/justice/redemption/love/whatever. Pretty standard fair so far but with a different coat, or so you might think.

However here's where the managing kicks in: you can't just fight tournaments and do sidequests, oh no. You have to eat, sleep, keep your mood up and make money to fund your journey. In a way you encounter all the problems you would realistically expect if you just decided to go from nobody to boxer, you have to waste away much of your day and effort in the gym to get buff, have to get some actual experience fighting and all this can't be done on an empty stomach either, so you have to eat. As an amateur boxer any money you win will not even cover the food expenses, so you're going to need to do a job, which in turn saps your energy that you will need to also train... you get the idea. Managing all these activities is part of the challenge and fun of the game.

Unfortunately I often found that I ended up settling into a routine of grinding cash, spending half a day recovering and then grinding the gym just before the scheduled fight as low energy doesn't affect fight outcome. I could literally go totally exhausted from the gym right into the boxing match and be on even standing with my opponent. Basically the gameplay promotes finding a routine that works and grinding it over and over with events, sidequests and optional fights serving as a welcome distraction from it.

And grind you will, physical stats rise fairly fast: you can go from wimpy nobody to hulk levels of strenght in what ammounts to less than a year ingame just by following a set routine. At the price that you also have to overcome gradually increasing stat decay. Yes, physical stats decay and you're likely going to have to settle either to concentrate on one or two, or investing into skills that lock them at a set level. Still the decay seems to serve mostly to prolong the grind and even more to motivate the player to follow a routine, cause heaven forbid you miss out a week of going to the gym and loose several stat points.

The stats themselves are interesting, they come with an advantage as well as a drawback, which is something I haven't seen before in an rpg game. Say you go for a high strenght build like I did: you'll quickly find out that if your super powerful attacks miss, all of a sudden your character is depleted of energy and turned into a punching bag for the nimble opponent who'll happily exploit your lack of ability to dodge or recover fast enough.

Long story short: more strenght means higher energy consumption, which means having to also raise stamina, which means now one has to overcome stat decay of not one but two stats. But then the higher your strenght and stamina the lower your hit and dodge chances, so you need to also level your agility or else rely on luck that you'll hit your opponent before they critically cripple you.

Basically stats come with ups and downs and their proportion seems more important than the actual number, or so was my experience. Starting a second game of 1STR/5AGI/1STA I won a training fight easily, however with a 5/5/5 ration the same fight was repeatedly narrowly lost! I'll leave to your consideration whether that's a clever or rubbish system, but I was intrigued by it if nothing else.

Some perks were similiar too, the higher level ones in particular also came with negative effects and seemed to have been tailored for specialized strategies, like a perk that diassalowed my character to block, or even defend at all in exchange for higher damage. Sucks if you invested in those abilities earlier on and now they become useless. And sucks more if not taking that disabling perk prevents you from getting a good one behind it. Still the skill trees are big and varied offering a huge variety of choice, haven't had nearly enough time to experiment with all the possibilities.

The combat itself feels more like something out of a managing sim than an rpg. You don't actually control your character only pick a selection of skills your character prepares between rounds and then watch them fight till the next round or a knockout. Your input is picking the right strategy and hoping your character can execute it. Random chance can screw you over and it probably will every once in a while. Not for those who can't stand loosing a dice roll.

As for the game style and looks, it has a faux retro feel. The game mimics old SNES style, complete with retro sound effects, music and graphics a storyline that seems to take itself half serious, throwing in a reference/shoutout to rocky, fight club, street fighter, wrestling... However the story itself got incredibly stale towards the end, with nothing to do and nothing interesting happening between grinding and bossfights. I really wish the last part of the game received more attention as the felt very bland compared to the more fun first half.

In the end its a fun game, there's reasons to like and dislike it. It is unique enough to be memorable, has its own charm and is somewhat of a mix between a managerial/sim genre and an rpg. This alone sets it apart and made it worth the play for me. However the disadvantage is the grind you will have to go through to get the neccesary stats and skills to win, as well as some reliance on random chance at times (more for some stat builds than others). If you hate those things stay away, otherwise I'd recommend the game for those who like the style.

reviewText:
I'm going to tentatively thumbs-up this one. It has great basic mechanics and is really well put-together. I thought I would really hate that you don't get to actively control the character during fights, but it's actually still pretty fun. You get to chose which moves they use during each round, and there's strong strategic elements to it.

The game's main flaw is that it is really, really difficult. Frustratingly so. I get that they wanted to provide a challenge, but it ends up being more frustrating than fun most of the time, for me. Each day you lose stats, and it really just feels like you're being robbed. You have to manage your time carefully to make any progress at all, and if you fail, then your character slowly spirals into decay. Also, the matches can't be skipped, sped up, or forfeited by any means that I'm aware of, which sucks when you are slowly losing over the course of five rounds.

tl;dr: Great game, but too frustrating. Needs lower difficulty option.

reviewText:
More Reviews @ TheVideogameBacklog.com

This review is without the Dark Fist content.

Holy cow Punch Club is addicting. While on the surface it looks like a simplistic boxing game, I think labeling it as such would be a bit misleading. It’s more of a micro-management/sim game with a boxing theme. At first I thought this was kind of a silly idea, but after getting lost in the ins and outs of Punch Club it really pulls you in with its atmosphere and throwbacks to some of my favorite movies and TV shows. Punch Club has a lot of charm.

It’s more of a micro-management/sim game with a boxing theme. It’s more of a micro-management/sim game with a boxing theme. Punch Club has a lot of charm.

Score: Gewd./Tasty!

There is a lot to love here with all the heart-throttlelingly intense wins and loses RNG can bring you. After you come to terms with the fact that Punch Club isn’t a free roaming Fight Club game where you can just do whatever you want and build to your heart’s content and more of a boxing management sim which tells a story, everything gets better. I love all of the Stallone references and the general 80’s shout outs from posters to the van in your garage. If you don’t try to get too deep into the talent trees, you’ll probably beat this game with a good/solid love for Punch Club. If you try to grind it out, you’ll probably get burned out. That’s never a good thing. Enjoy the story and then play it again and go to jail or make a straight Agility build with no strength because you know that’s what you want to do even if it’s nerfed. We all want to be ninja’s because ninja’s are cool.

reviewText:
This key was obtained from the publisher for the purposes of review.

Summary:
Some simulation games while nice at first, can get rather easy in the long run....but not Punch Club. And that's a good thing. Great balance with the different mechanics available leads to an actual challenge, as the wrong moves will set you back significantly and you won't make promise. While at times this will lead to frustration, there's a bunch of different strategies that you will have to implement based on the current situation, and there was an actual smart decision made by the developers here to be not directly involved in the fight. It puts the emphasis on the training elements of the game, but still allows you strategy by selecting the appropriate skills that you will need to counteract your opponents strengths, or maybe complement your own. Most of the problems that the game in the simulator genre are more on the minor side, with the aesthetic (while alright) isn't exactly the greatest, I'd rather have keyboard controls implemented with some of the menus, just to make things easier.  But in the end, it's a great simulator game that I enjoyed my time with, with multiple reasons to come back to it.

Video Review: https://youtu.be/nBAxHTwm37g

Lists:
+:
A Difficult but still fair simulator that actually punishes you for not taking advantage of the situations, and makes it so that you may not make progress at times. Forces the player to actually sit down and look at every option available to them.
Strong strategy elements in the combat element because of the lack of direct control by the player. Forces smart decision making and taking advantage of what's in front of you. Like the imiplementation of stamina and what it means if you don't have any left.
Skill Tree has significant choices that actually mean something, more then just the 3 major stats. Each skill have sub elements to it means you can specialize even further, like being an aggressive boxer that goes for stamina.
Good Design on the temporary boosts so that you had to earn them, but when you did, they actually meant something.
Good balance between the different aspects of work/training/etc. Couldn't rush one, had to do them all.
Liked the TMNT reference. Even if it was corny.
-:
At times, do wish there was at least a hint of what you were getting into, as in some cases, you'd get your ♥♥♥ kicked because you did something way before you should of.
Small annoyance with not knowing exactly what I need to complete missions or how close I am at times, wondering if I'm putting effort in that is ultimately pointless.
There's a small pause at times after selecting something, and sometimes the hourglass sticks around even though I can click on something.
Keyboard shortcuts. Would have loved them. Options in general seem to be lacking.
Battle animations will get repetitive. Would have loved a way to speed up the action during them.
STOP ROBBING ME RIGHT BEFORE A BIG PURCHASE. This really just annoyed me. How does he know how much money I have on hand at all times?

reviewText:
Punch Club is a fun and addictive, fighter management game with some RPG and Tycoon elements. If you enjoy 80's and 90's themed fighting movies, then this will be right up your alley.

The art style, sound and music are a great throw back to the day of old, but don't let the look fool you.   It has a surprising amount of depth, and is actually pretty tough.

It remains challenging to manage all your stats and finances whilst at the same time keeping up your training and preparing for the next big fight. It's got that one more fight type of hook.

Even though you don't directly control the fights themselves, there are fair mount lot of tactical choices and build customization to choose from for you fighter. Choose your abilities based on your characters strengths, and who your opponent is and what skills they are using.

There is a story as well, with branching choices that can be made, as well as different endings. That and the ability to play your fighter using a differ build will definitely add some replayablity.

The only thing I would have to criticize in my time with the game so far is the lack of music variety.
There is only really 1 track that plays while you are going about your daily tasks, and it eventually starts to get repetitive. After turning down the music volume to 20% it was better. Having other tracks or even less busy background music in those sections would've been nice.

I've made a video just taking a look at the game here

https://youtu.be/3o_Q7Hr4ILc

Great surprise and came out of nowhere!

The developers were nice enough to provide me with a code for the game. Did that effect my opinion of the game? No. I still think its great and worth picking up.

If you like the this style of game I'd highly recommend it, one of  the better fighter management games out there.

EDIT: I finished the game yesterday at around day 253 using an agility based build.

Toward the end it got kind of repetitive, but it turns out that was due to a bug, which caused goals to take longer to reach than they should've, which I believe has since been fixed.

All in all I still recommend the game. The dev's have been pretty active in balancing and fixing stuff so far and I'm looking forward to trying out another build with my 2nd playthrough :)
